outcome.outcome_text: Demonstrate understanding of oral French messages in limited questions, statements, courtesy requests, instructions and accolades. [L] [R]

indicator.p: Associates oral words with pictures or gestures to indicate understanding (e.g., points at a picture, makes a gesture, draws a picture or matches words to a picture).
Associates oral words with concrete items (e.g., selects clothing items to put into a suitcase or selects fruit or vegetables to use in a recipe).
Follows directions (e.g., to go to a room in a house or school or to select body parts to create an imaginary animal).
Responds to questions beginning with Où (e.g., by pointing to a room in a classroom, house or school or by saying the word in French).
Responds to questions beginning with qui (e.g., by pointing to a person or saying their name).
Responds to Qu’est-ce que c’est?/Est-ce que c’est...? in English or with a single word in French.
Responds to a request ending with s’il vous plait with a courtesy response such as Oui, madame.
Responds to a courtesy request for a food item (e.g., Un sandwich, s’il vous plait! or by giving the appropriate item to the person making the request).
Responds appropriately to a wide range of accolades (e.g., Bien! Très bien! Bravo! Excellent! Super! Formidable! ) with an appropriate gesture, facial expression or Merci ).
Follows several familiar action-oriented instructions to complete a task, (e.g., Sors ton cahier. Découpe la photo. Colle la photo dans ton cahier. )
Follows instructions (e.g., how to perform a dance or play a game with actions).
Matches a spoken French word or phrase with actions or gestures.

outcome.outcome_text: Provide basic information on familiar topics supported by a range of prompting as required. [S] [L]

indicator.p: Replies to a courtesy response such as Merci! with De rien.
Replies to questions such as Comment ça va? with an appropriate response as well as adding: Et toi?
Replies to an offer with expressions such as Oui, merci beaucoup! or Non, merci! Un crayon, s’il vous plait.
Replies to farewells with expressions such as Salut! Au revoir! or À bientôt!.
Describes people, animals, actions or weather in an oral sentence (e.g., Il/Elle a les cheveux blonds. Il/Elle est grand(e). Il fait beau. L’animal a une queue. Je coupe la pomme. ).
Answers questions (e.g., Qu’est-ce que c’est? Qui est-ce? Où est maman? ) with a correctly structured oral sentence.
Instructs a classmate to perform an action (e.g., Coupe la pomme. Va dans le couloir. ).

Makes an oral sentence containing a list of items (e.g., Je mets deux t-shirts, une paire de sandales, une paire de shorts et un maillot de bain dans ma valise. Il y a deux cahiers, trois livres et deux crayons dans mon sac. ).
Makes a sentence indicating preferences or non preferences (e.g., J’aime les barres de granola. Je déteste les sandwichs. ).
Makes a sentence indicating feelings (e.g., J’ai une pizza….je suis content(e)! J’ai un sandwich….je suis triste! J’ai une salade…je suis surprise! ).
Uses a previously learned sentence to participate in an oral language game with others.

outcome.outcome_text: Demonstrate understanding of key words and content in a series of simple, repetitive sentences supported by illustrations or photos. [R] [RP]

indicator.p: Locates key words and cognates in a group of repetitive sentences accompanied by illustrations.
Matches key words and cognates to illustrations (e.g., C’est l’été. Je porte des sandales. Je porte des shorts. Je porte un t-shirt. ).
Sorts key words according to several criteria, e.g., rooms of the house/rooms of the schoolhealthy/non-healthy foodswinter/summer clothing.
States the content in a series of repetitive sentences such as by stating a single French word or in English.
Responds to questions about a shared reading experience (e.g., with actions, gestures, known French words, or English words).

outcome.outcome_text: Produce a simple and repetitive text on a familiar topic based on a model. [W]

indicator.p: Writes a sentence by substituting one word in a modeled sentence.

Writes a repetitive 4-5 sentence modeled text such as one that describes the selection of foods needed for a healthy lunch (e.g., Voici mon lunch. J’ai une banane. J’ai un sandwich. J’ai du lait. J’ai des carottes. C’est bon! ).

Makes a poster of items needed for a trip to a certain destination, accompanied by two sentences (e.g., J’ai des shorts dans ma valise. J’ai un t-shirt dans ma valise. J’ai des espadrilles dans ma valise. ).

outcome.outcome_text: Use listening or viewing strategies in structured situations. [L] [V] [RP]

indicator.p: Before listening or viewing: Describes, using a familiar French word, what is seen in a picture, or a photograph.
Before listening or viewing: Predicts the content of an oral presentation (e.g., selecting pictures or matching key words to pictures).
Before listening or viewing: Makes connections to own experience in English on what he or she knows about the subject as announced in the title.
During listening or viewing: Identifies key words and cognates (e.g., for words that indicate people, animals, place, time, dates and weather).
During listening or viewing: Tolerates ambiguity by focusing on known words and phrases.
During listening or viewing: Interprets gestures, facial images, intonation and expression to understand a message.
During listening or viewing: Tells about a mental image in English.
After listening or viewing: Verifies predictions made before listening.
After listening or viewing: Identifies the content of the listening experience (e.g., saying a familiar key word or phrase or drawing a picture).
After listening or viewing: Identifies, in English, the strategies used to interpret the message.
After listening or viewing: Asks questions in English about content that was not understood.

outcome.outcome_text: Use speaking strategies in structured situations. [L] [V] [S]

indicator.p: Plans what to say in a conversation, such as by writing key words or by discussing with a partner.
Makes attempts to say new words and phrases orally.
Refers to charts, pictures and bulletin boards as memory supports while speaking.
Refers to models while speaking (e.g., delivery of a weather report, or explanation of a procedure such as how to make a snack).
Refers to diagrams to give instructions on performing a series of actions.
Practises simple requests and expression of feelings with a partner.
Makes gestures to accompany sentences.
Self-evaluates participation in oral activities through the use of satisfaction indicators (e.g., Pas trop bien. Assez bien. Bien. Très bien. Excellent. ).

outcome.outcome_text: Use reading strategies for short, repetitive texts in highly structured situations. [L] [V] [R]

indicator.p: Before shared reading: Predicts the content of the text (e.g., by matching a key word to a picture or by using a familiar French word with prompting).
Before shared reading: Makes connections to own experience in English on what he or she knows about the subject as announced in the title.
During shared reading: Identifies key words and cognates (e.g., people, animals, place, time and weather).
During shared reading: Identifies and uses parts of illustrations and photos to aid understanding.
During shared reading: Examines charts, posters or visual and personal dictionaries to access meaning.
During shared reading: Reads along with the teacher as the text is re-read.
During shared reading: Tells about a mental image using a French word or phrase.
After shared reading: Verifies predictions made before reading.
After shared reading: Identifies the content of the written text (e.g., saying a familiar key word or phrase or drawing a picture).
After shared reading: Indicates level of comprehension of the text (e.g., by pointing to traffic light colours).
After shared reading: Asks questions in English, with prompting, about content that was not understood.

outcome.outcome_text: Follow modeled steps of a shortened writing process in highly structured situations. [W] [S] [R]

indicator.p: Offers familiar expressions or single-word ideas as the teacher models the writing of a short text.
Refers to word lists such as a personal dictionary.
Refers to references (e.g., bulletin boards, charts and visual or online dictionaries).
Discusses with a teacher or a partner single word ideas to put into the text.
Substitutes words in a modeled text.
Self-evaluates writing through the use of familiar satisfaction indicators (e.g., Pas trop bien. Assez bien. Bien. Très bien. Excellent. ).

outcome.outcome_text: Demonstrate acquisition of French language concepts related to themes, including: numbers 1-50various question typespossessive pronouns for personal itemspossessionadjectives indicating attributes of self and othersa variety of instructions or commands.knowledge of key vocabulary words and phrases linked to themes. [S] [R] [RP]

indicator.p: Counts to 50.
Names numbers 1-50 in French.
Explains the difference, in English, between questions beginning with où , qui , and que .
Refers to objects that belong to himself or herself using a possessive pronoun (e.g., ma valise, ma boîte à lunch, ma chambre, ma maison, mon animal ).
Uses the verb avoir to show possession of an object, such as J’ai une pomme .
Uses the verb être to show personal attributes (e.g., Je suis grand, Elle est petite ).
Uses the verbs chercher, mettre, aller to indicate instructions.

Demonstrates an understanding of key thematic words and phrases in a simple oral sentence: NumbersWeather ReportMy HousePeople in the SchoolImaginary AnimalsTravel ClothingTrash-less LunchesFolk and Traditional DancesShort Trip Destinations.

outcome.outcome_text: Compare basic elements of Francophone, First Nations, and Métis family cultures in communities. [S] [RP]

indicator.p: Represents French culture (e.g., by reciting a comptine or by singing a song).

Identifies traditional Francophone foods in a lunch (e.g., les croissants, le fromage ), in comparison to foods in First Nations and Métis cultures (e.g., les baies (berries) and la banique (bannock)).
Examines elements of French culture in the classroom and school, such as posters and books.

Describes housing types in various Francophone communities (e.g., une maison à deux étages, une villa, une maison mobile, un bungalow, un hôtel de glace ) in comparison to the various kinds of traditional housing in First Nations and Métis cultures ( un tipi, une cabane ).
Examines meals in different Francophone communities (e.g., déjeuner/petit déjeuner and diner/souper. ).
Describes mythic or imaginary animals such as the sea monster Memphré in Québecois culture in comparison to animals such as Coyote in many First Nations cultures.
Discusses authentic French picture books read by the teacher.
Uses knowledge of Francophone cultures to participate in cultural activities (e.g., games, singing, and chants).
Self-evaluates participation in cultural activities through the use of satisfaction indicators (e.g., Pas trop bien. Assez bien. Bien. Très bien. Excellent. ).
